bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, May 6, 1942

div1.p: Hench is forwarding Blossom Reed's manuscript, which includes some Walter Reed letters. He comments that Walter Reed would be dismayed if he knew that Blossom was attempting to sell his personal letters.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, May 6, 1942
div1.p:
I am sending you, at long last, Miss Reed's manuscript and I am
taking a chance on you, because Blossom has left it up to me as to whether
to send it to you. Apparently I “sold” myself to her rather over-effectively
and she thinks I am “wonderful”! She feels that what I have written about
her father has been done for love and she says that what others are writing
about him is done for money. But of course that isn't entirely true. No
writer gets enough from a book to make it worthwhile and certainly yours
is largely a labor of love. She is leaving it to me to decide whether to
send you the manuscript and you will remember that my main concern about
it is that I came by it rather left-handedly, getting it not directly from
Blossom but from Kellogg. However, Blossom knows that I have a copy and
is willing to let me have it. Her main concern is that we shall not quote
from it and I can understand her viewpoint. She is still trying to sell
it. Of course, some of the letters have been published already and those
which have been published you can quote, giving the source other than
Blossom's manuscript. I am sending it to you with the understanding, there-
fore, that you will merely use it as background information and to check
the whereabouts of General Reed.

I am not surprised that she has been unable to sell it in the form
that she submitted it, as the letters are so personal that they are at times
a little “sticky”! Poor Walter would probably turn over in his grave if
he knew his daughter was trying to sell those letters.

There are a number of obvious mistakes in the letters--an occasional
wrong date, and a few other items that I haven't been able to get corrections
for. Notice in one spot he mentions sailing down the coast of Florida viewing
the scenery from twenty miles off shore! He must have had exceptional eyesight.
Please return the manuscript to me at your earliest convenience.

I am sorry not to have acknowledge the receipt of the other material.
I have had a most hectic two months. I just completed a course of fifty six
lectures to fifty doctors sent here by the American College of Physicians.
Fifteen or sixteen of the lectures were given by myself and I was chairman of
practically all of the discussions.

Please remember me to your good husband and best wishes for the early
completion of your manuscript.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
